taxonomicNotes: According to the World Spider Catalog Macrothele should be placed in its own family the Macrothelidae.
The taxon is a member of the H. nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
The taxon is a member of the Hylaeus nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
This species belongs to a highly diverse taxonomic group, which is not yet fully understood. It is probably a local variant only and is closely related to Hylaeus hyalinatus.
The subgeneric attribution of Andrena ebmerella is uncertain.
Described in 1993 as one of four species identified within a species complex (with P. budensis, P. caucasicus and other). Delimitation and distributional ranges are not yet clear.
It was previously described as a subspecies of S. marginatus but it is thought to be a separate species (Bogusch and Straka in prep.).

The current edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The current edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The first edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue to be published in 2015, all the subgenera will be upgraded to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The first edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue to be published in 2015, all the subgenera will be upgraded to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear as the species is only known from the type specimens (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
Should be Allancastria (see Bollini and Racheli 2012).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear as the species is only known from the type specimen (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
Ramme (1939) described this species as Rhacocleis silvestrii, named after Prof. F. Silvestri-Portici, but it is often cited as Rhacocleis sylvestrii.

The taxonomic status of this species is a matter of debate (Gorochov 2009, 2012). It may be a subspecies of Gryllomorpha dalmatina but this issue has not been definitely settled yet. The taxon was described as Gryllomorpha cretensis by Ramme (1927), however Eades et al. (2014) place the taxon as a subspecies of Gryllomorpha dalmatina Ramme, 1927. Gorochov and Ünal (2012) mentions G. cretensis in the context of G. dalmatina (p.54-55) but the text there states: "The first taxon [i.e. Gryllomorpha cretensis] is insufficiently studied, and its belonging to G. dalmatina is not evident; however, a single female from Crete I., recently studied by us, is similar to Ramme’s description and distinguished from the above-mentioned Turkish specimens as well as from the other Greek and Montenegro specimens by the smaller body size and transversally banded (not spotted) colouration of abdominal dorsum; this is probably a separate subspecies." In addition, the paper itself does not make the new combination. Although future studies may indeed prove this to be a subspecies of G. dalmatina, at present we retain G. cretensis as a species (L. Willemse pers. comm. 2015).

This species was described from the eastern Aegean island of Kos (Baccetti 1992). Baccetti described this species on the basis of the studies of Krimbas (1956a, 1956b, 1960), who found two Gryllotalpa species with different chromosome numbers in Greece. G. krimbasi has 19 chromosomes and Baccetti considered his specimen as typical for this form which was found by Krimbas in many places of the Greek mainland (see map 109a in Willemse 1984). Ingrisch et al. (2006) present further morphological details of krimbasi after material from Fthiotis, Central Greece, with a chromosome number of about 19

Acrometopa cretensis is a species with two subspecies: A. cretensis cretensis and A. cretensis daedali; see also the Orthoptera Species File (orthoptera.speciesfile.org/). This assessment is based on (distribution) data of the species.

Zeuner (1941) described Parnassiana tymphrestos from Mt.Timfristos (= Mt. Veluchi, compare Ramme, 1931). Ramme (1951) discussed the possible synonymy of P. tymphrestos and P. coracis but, not being aware that Mt. Korax is close to Mt. Timfristos, and by lack of material of P. tymphrestos, did not solve it, and the matter remains unsolved. For the time being, the material from Mt. Vardhousia recorded under P. tymphrestos in F. Willemse (1980 & 1984) should be transferred to Platycleis (Parnassiana) coracis Ramme, 1920. Likewise a re-evaluation of the population of Mt. Oiti, also arranged under P. tymphrestos in F. Willemse (1973 & 1980) appears necessary.

The identity of Rhacocleis agiostratica is not beyond doubt as the description has been based on juvenile specimens. Adult material is required to compare it with other Rhacocleis species in particular Rhacocleis distinguenda.

Alosterna pauli Pesarini, Rapuzzi & Sabbadini, 2004 was described in the group of species related to A. anatolica Adlbauer, 1992 and A. tabacicolor (De Geer, 1775) (Adlbauer 1992, Pesarini and Sabbadini 2004). It differs from them on the basis of strong elements while the description paper gives precise drawings. Some mistakes remain in the documentation, like in Fauna Europaea where the description date is 2003 (De Jong et al. 2014) or wrong bibliographic reference for the description (Tavakilian and Chevillotte 2012).

In 1985, Sláma described Brachyleptura martini from Crete. However, the name was preoccupied by Leptura semirufula var. martini (Pic, 1945) described from Madrid, and thereafter synonym of Stictoleptura trisignata (Fairmaire, 1852). So, when Brachyleptura was included in the new genus Stictoleptura, the species of Sláma was changed to S. slamai Sama, 2010.
Placed within the subgenus Petrochilosina. The species name was erroneously spelled 'octhoniai' in the title, abstract and discussion of the describing paper (Alexiou et al. 2015).

Formerly, Boyeria cretensis was confused with—and regarded as a subpopulation of—Boyeria irene (Fonscolombe, 1838), but both species are clearly distinct (Boudot 1989, Peters 1991, Kohli et al. 2014).

Three subspecies have been described: Cordulegaster helladica helladica, C. h. buchholzi and C. h. kastalia, but the separation between them remains very difficult and even intermediate forms between those subspecies have been described.

This newly-recognized European monotypic genus has been discovered and described recently (Vujić et al. 2019). The systematic position of the taxon is within the tribe Rhingiini. Katara connexa is shiny, black species with broad, oval abdomen, which is distinctly broader than thorax in both sexes. Eyes are separated in both sexes (Vujić et al. 2019).
Cheilosia katara belongs to nominal subgenus Cheilosia. An identification key distinguishing C. katara from other related species was provided by Vujić and Claussen (2000).

authority: J. van Steenis and W. van Steenis, 2014

taxonomicNotes: The species is very close to P. globulicollis and its status (valid species or subspecies of P. globulicollis) is unclear, pending molecular data (Rapuzzi and Sama 2013).
This species is considered a subspecies of Cordulegaster helladica, but given the closeness of the two taxa, genetic investigations are in work to provide new taxonomic information.
In addition to the nominotypical one, two subspecies have been described, namely C. h. buchholzi (Lohmann, 1993) and C. h. kastalia (Lohmann, 1993).
This species is considered a subspecies of Cordulegaster helladica but genetic investigations are in work to get new informations about the systematic position of the various members of C. helladica.

Cheilosia candida Vujić et Radenković, 2020 is a member of the subgenus Convocheila Barkalov, and endemic to Europe. The species was described based on a single male specimen. Radenković et al. (2020) provide images of the male, including the male genitalia, and an identification key to separate the species from all other members of subgenus Convocheila. The species is morphologically similar to C. paralobi Malski, and distinguishing characters are provided in Radenković et al. (2020).
